fill-in-the-blank-questions.question: In an effort to preserve historical documents, the museum created a _________ of the ancient manuscript, allowing visitors to handle a replica without risking damage to the original.
The art student's final project was a remarkable _________ of Van Gogh's "Starry Night," meticulously replicating the original's brushwork and color palette.
The rare book collector was thrilled to add a _________ of the 15th-century manuscript to his collection, as the original was far beyond his reach, both financially and geographically.
During the restoration of the medieval castle, architects used _________ materials to replace the damaged stonework, ensuring the new sections were indistinguishable from the old.
The science fiction novel featured a technology that could produce a _________ of any object, down to the atomic level, leading to profound questions about identity and originality.
To ensure the authenticity of the reproduced artwork, the curator included a certificate stating that the piece is a _________, not the original.
The detective novel's plot thickened when a _________ of the missing will surfaced, throwing into question the legitimacy of the document that had been found earlier.
With the rise of digital archives, libraries began offering _________ versions of rare books, allowing scholars to access texts that were previously unavailable to them.
In an effort to combat counterfeiting, the government introduced new currency features that made creating a convincing _________ nearly impossible.

As part of the exhibit on ancient civilizations, the museum displayed a _________ of the Rosetta Stone, allowing visitors to touch and feel the inscriptions that led to the deciphering of Egyptian hieroglyphs.
In the courtroom, the evidence presented included a _________ of the original handwritten note, ensuring the jury could examine its contents without handling the fragile original.
The author's biography included several _________ of her personal letters, giving readers insight into her thoughts and feelings in a way that paraphrasing could not.
For the movie's production, the prop department created a _________ of the legendary sword, so detailed that it was nearly impossible for the audience to tell it wasn't the authentic artifact.

examples.example: Already the sudden storm is passing, and its fierceness is abating; crowds are scattering homeward, and the sky is beginning to redden over the Yorkshire wolds.

09b124e8-0b7b-48f0-9d50-c499c8ccbb80.background: *Abate* comes from the Old French verb *abattre*, "to beat down," and means to reduce or become less intense or numerous. As an intransitive verb, it is often used with something physically, emotionally, or figuratively violent, as in "the flood of fan mail began to *abate*." Using it transitively, if you take measures to abate pollution or noise, you reduce them. Pronounce *abate* with the stress on the second syllable (uh-BATE).
09b124e8-0b7b-48f0-9d50-c499c8ccbb80.definition: become less in amount or intensity
09b124e8-0b7b-48f0-9d50-c499c8ccbb80.blurb: Something that *abates* becomes fewer or less intense. Your enthusiasm for skiing might *abate* after falling off a ski lift and getting a mouthful of snow.

0a17d9e1-307e-45df-8923-850ce146611d.definition: the outcome of a complex sequence of events

examples.example: I have already intimated that my condition was much worse, during the first six months of my stay at Mr. Covey’s, than in the last six.
Diana intimated that this would be a different parting from any they had ever yet known.
When the cheering had died down, Napoleon, who had remained on his feet, intimated that he too had a few words to say.
But surviving testimony intimates that it was well on its way.

examples.example: She was one of the few things abhorrent to him that he could touch and therefore hurt.

a905047c-d936-457e-a766-dec674e932ba.background: When you think of *abhorrent*, think of *horror*, as in something so vile and loathsome that you can only react to it in horror. In fact, the word *abhorrent* in Latin means “to recoil (back away) in horror.” Note that the ending is spelled *-ent* with an *e*, not an *a*. Maybe the *a* found *abhorrent* so abhorrent that it didn’t want to appear in it a second time.
a905047c-d936-457e-a766-dec674e932ba.blurb: Many people find cruelty toward animals *abhorrent*, that is, they think it's detestable, obscene, repugnant, repulsive, and offensive to the mind. In other words, they really, really don't like it.

ab38c823-badc-4267-9666-2d2a55dc922c.definition: resembling a maze in form or complexity
ab38c823-badc-4267-9666-2d2a55dc922c.blurb: *Labyrinthine* is a good word to describe a place that feels like an enormous maze. A new student at a huge, sprawling high school is likely to find the building *labyrinthine* as she wanders the halls looking for her math class.

examples.example: And yet when he says, “I am from outer space,” some of you actually shut your eyes, abase your intellects, and believe!
“Should I abase myself? Rub ashes in my hair? Tear my clothes?”
Rather they are measurements of the amount of time that stick-figure heads bob up and down or left and right to fawn over the person who is president or to abase his flaws.
Cojocaru especially was a force of nature, the moment where she fell on her knees before Kobborg had a reckless, raw abandon that made the gesture anything but self abasing.
Much of the classical music industry has since abased itself at Mäkelä’s feet.
Yet when she isn’t mooning or abasing herself to win the attention of a handsome fellow intern, she shows off a preternatural self-possession, the girl with all the answers.
Before the company, she reiterated the ballet’s gesture of amorous veneration, making her arms a halo that she drew over his head, shoulders, torso, and legs, abasing herself at his feet.

But one German theologian has recently proposed explanatory footnotes to turn the most problematic passages — the black children abasing themselves before Pippi, for example — into educational opportunities.

ed250f4d-c049-4404-9729-7d16ed4f562a.background: *Abase* means to bring someone down, often either in their job or their self-esteem. The early Latin *bassus*, which meant "thick, low," evolved into the Old French *abaissier*, meaning "to make lower in value or status." The important clue to the word is "base." Consider that the base of anything is the bottom, and you get an idea as to the meaning of the word *abase*, which means to make someone feel low.
ed250f4d-c049-4404-9729-7d16ed4f562a.definition: cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of
ed250f4d-c049-4404-9729-7d16ed4f562a.blurb: To *abase* something or someone is to humiliate them — no, more than just humiliate them. If you *abase* another person you are bringing them low, humbling them in a mean, *base* manner. Not nice at all.

f5d64c05-19c1-4706-a7aa-925dc179d1a2.definition: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.
f5d64c05-19c1-4706-a7aa-925dc179d1a2.blurb: To *adorn* is to dress something up by decorating it. You might *adorn* your poncho with fringe or your poodle's dog collar with rhinestones.

fa3b6b23-50d4-4084-9a3e-2b5c562db196.definition: a roundabout or indirect way of speaking; the use of more words than necessary to express an idea

fd25b061-f2e6-4b4e-9ce0-b4ee86b93920.definition: be confusing or perplexing to; cause to be unable to think clearly
